name: dibenz[a,h]anthracene
source: Sepassi K; Yalkowsky SH; AAPS PharmSciTech; 7(1); E1-E8 (2006)

name: dibenz[a,h]anthracene
source: Sepassi K; Yalkowsky SH; AAPS PharmSciTech; 7(1); E1-E8 (2006)
Reason: The basic unit for comparison is benzene which has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. Dibenz[a,h]anthracene is a polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon consisting of four fused benzene rings, which significantly increases the molecular complexity and rigidity of the structure, resulting in a higher melting point. Fused benzene rings: each additional ring adds approximately +60 to +100 degrees Celsius because of increased pi-pi interactions and molecular rigidity. Predicting a roughly additive effect of these increments for four rings would result in an increase of (+60 * 3) to (+100 * 3), since the first ring is our reference point (benzene itself).

name: dibenz[a,h]anthracene
source: Sepassi K; Yalkowsky SH; AAPS PharmSciTech; 7(1); E1-E8 (2006)
Reason: The basic unit for comparison is benzene which has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. Dibenz[a,h]anthracene is a polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon consisting of four fused benzene rings, which significantly increases the molecular complexity and rigidity of the structure, resulting in a higher melting point. Fused benzene rings: each additional ring adds approximately +60 to +100 degrees Celsius because of increased pi-pi interactions and molecular rigidity. However, since the actual value of the melting point for dibenz[a,h]anthracene is 270 degrees Celsius, the effect of each fused benzene ring beyond the first should be estimated to give a total of approximately +264.5 degrees Celsius to match the actual value.
